citation.article-title: Proposal that the arsenite-oxidizing organisms Thiomonas cuprina and ‘Thiomonas arsenivorans’ be reclassified as strains of Thiomonas delicata, and emended description of Thiomonas delicata
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Emended description of Thiomonas delicata (Katayama-Fujimura et al., 1984) Katayama et al. 2006, Kelly and Wood, 2006
Thiomonas delicata (del.i.cat′a. L. fem. adj. delicata delicate).
Basonym: Thiobacillus delicatus (ex Mizoguchi et al., 1976) Katayama-Fujimura et al., 1984.
Cells are rods, usually single, occurring rarely in pairs and 0.4–0.6×1.0–4.0 µm.
The type strain is non-motile, but other strains are motile with a single polar flagellum.
Colonies grown on yeast extract–thiosulfate agar are 1 mm in diameter, smooth and circular and change from transparent to whitish-yellow with sulfur.
Facultative chemolithotroph and mixotroph.

The type strain oxidizes As(III), and grows autotrophically on arsenopyrite, sulfur, thiosulfate and tetrathionate but not with thiocyanate; accumulates tetrathionate and trithionate transiently during growth on thiosulfate.
Some strains also grow on chalcopyrite, but not on thiosulfate, and some strains also grow lithoautotrophically on As(III), sphalerite, galena, hydrogen sulfide and elemental sulfur.

Some strains grow chemoorganotrophically on one or more single organic compounds, including pyruvate, succinate, aspartate and glutamate, but none grow on glucose, fructose, galactose, mannose, lactose, arabinose, sorbose, sorbitol, ribose, sucrose, raffinose, acetate, ethanol, propanol, glycerol, oxalate, lactate, malate, gluconate, 2-oxoglutarate, citrate, alanine, glycine, serine, cysteine, proline, lysine or histidine.
The type strain does not grow with any single organic compound.
Grows mixotrophically with thiosulfate as an energy source in mineral media supplemented with intermediates of the tricarboxylic acid cycle, amino acids or yeast extract.
Grows on rich media (yeast extract, meat extract, peptone, casamino acids).

The type strain is facultatively anaerobic, reduces nitrate and produces nitrite in mixotrophic and autotrophic media with thiosulfate or tetrathionate, but does not denitrify nitrate to nitrogen gas.
Ammonium salts, nitrate, urea, glutamate and aspartate can be used as a sole nitrogen sources.
Growth occurs at 15–42 °C (optimum 30–35 °C) but not at 10 °C or 45 °C.
Grows at pH 3.0–7.0 (optimum pH 4.0–6.0; minimum pH 2.5–3.0, although some strains grow at pH 1.5) but not at pH 1.0 or pH 7.5.

The major fatty acids are C16 : 0 (25–33 %) and C18 : 1ω7c (33–43 %), with lesser amounts (0–25 %) of C10 : 0, C12 : 0, C14 : 0, C17 : 0, C18 : 0, C15 : 1ω6c, C16 : 1ω5c, C16 : 1, C17 : 1ω8c, cyclo-C17, cyclo-C19, C10 : 0 3-OH, C16 : 0 2-OH, C16 : 0 3-OH, C16 : 1 2-OH, C18 : 1 2-OH, 11-methyl C18 : 1ω7c, 10-methyl C19 : 0, iso-C10 : 0 3-OH fatty acids.
The respiratory quinone is ubiquinone Q-8.
Occurs in continental solfataric fields and drainage from sulfidic and arsenic-mineral mines.
The type strain is THI 091T ( = NBRC 14566T = IFO 14566T = KCTC 285T = DSM 17897T).
The DNA G+C content of the type strain is 66–67 mol% (Tm).
